channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: From a Space Station in Argentina, China Expands Its Reach in Latin America
item.media:description: The Chinese space station, including a 16-story-tall parabolic antenna, in a remote area of Argentina’s Patagonia region.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Our correspondent went to the deserts of Patagonia to examine how China secured its new base, a symbol of its growing clout in the region.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Facebook Is Failing to Aid Inquiry Into ‘Fake News,’ British Lawmakers Say
item.media:description: Demonstrators in London protested in April against Facebook in the wake of revelations that the social media giant had been used to spread “fake news” in an effort to influence elections in Europe and the United States.
item.description: In a report to be released Sunday, a parliamentary committee accused Facebook of providing “disingenuous” answers to questions and of withholding information.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Cardinal Theodore McCarrick Resigns Amid Sexual Abuse Scandal
item.media:description: An investigation found credible evidence that Cardinal Theodore McCarrick had sexually abused a teenager 47 years ago while serving as a priest in New York.
item.description: Pope Francis accepted his letter of resignation and ordered the former archbishop of Washington to remain in seclusion while accusations against him were being examined, the Vatican said.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and SHARON OTTERMAN

item.title: Turkish School Leader Abducted, and Released, in Mongolia
item.media:description: A passenger jet believed to be operated by the Turkish Air Force at the airport in Ulan Bator, Mongolia, on Friday. The Mongolian authorities grounded a Turkish jet amid protests over the abduction of a Turkish educator.
item.description: The seizure of Veysel Akcay, who was freed after supporters gathered at Ulan Bator’s airport, appeared to be part of Turkey’s campaign against allies of an exiled cleric.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH

item.title: Newest U.S. Strategy in Afghanistan Mirrors Past Plans for Retreat
item.media:description: An American outpost in the Afghanistan province of Nangarhar.
item.description: The Trump administration is pushing Afghan commanders to surrender rural and sparsely populated areas of the country and focus on protecting cities.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: An 11-Year-Old Girl Is Gang Raped in India and Blamed for It, Too
item.media:description: A police vehicle carrying men accused of raping an 11-year-old girl came under attack this month in Chennai, India.
item.description: When the police in Chennai, India, arrested 17 men accused of assaulting the girl, there was a wave of public fury. Then the narrative changed.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Go Home, South Korea Tells Workers, as Stress Takes Its Toll
item.media:description: Commuters in Seoul, South Korea. A new law caps the workweek for many employees at 52 hours.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Though Japan brought the world the concept of “death from overwork,” South Koreans actually work longer hours. The government is trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: SU-HYUN LEE and TIFFANY MAY

item.title: U.S. Diplomats Held Face-to-Face Talks With Taliban, Insurgents Say
item.media:description: The Taliban’s “political office” Doha, Qatar. The militant group has long maintained an informal political office here for the purpose of restarting the long-dormant peace process.
item.description: A senior State Department official was among diplomats who met with representatives from the Taliban in Doha, Qatar, a week ago, the insurgents said.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: After Pakistan’s Heated Election, Key Parties Lend Support to Imran Khan
item.media:description: A billboard of Imran Khan in Islamabad. The National Assembly has 272 contested seats, and Mr. Khan’s party has done far better than all the others, winning 115 seats.
item.description: Swing parties are coalescing around Imran Khan, the cricket star whose political party won Pakistan’s elections, paving the way for him to ascend to the premiership.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and DANIYAL HASSAN

item.title: Extremists Kill 2 at Afghan School for Midwives, but Students Escape
item.media:description: Afghan security officials secured a road leading to the midwifery school under attack in Jalalabad, in Nangarhar Province, on Saturday.
item.description: Security forces battled insurgents at a midwifery school in Jalalabad, and two attackers died. Three female students were wounded.
item.dc:creator: ZABIHULLAH GHAZI and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ‘I Think All Those People Are Dead’: Laos Dam Survivors Seek Word of Neighbors
item.media:description: Flooding in southern Laos has left more than 6,000 people homeless, according to the country’s official news agency.
item.media:credit: Ben C. Solomon/The New York Times
item.description: In shelters for victims of the dam failure in the south of the authoritarian country, official news is proving sparse and contradictory.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: ‘They Spit When I Walked in the Street’: The ‘New Anti-Semitism’ in France
item.media:description: A silent demonstration in Paris honoring Mireille Knoll, an 85-year-old Holocaust survivor who was killed in her Paris apartment in March.
item.description: A strong correlation has been observed between increases in hate crimes against French Jews and the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Putin Invites Trump to Moscow for Second Meeting After Washington Postponed Plans
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Friday that President Trump “has a wish to have further meetings, to hold further meetings, and I am ready for that.”
item.description: The Russian president continued to push for a second meeting, saying he was also ready to meet in Washington.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: ‘Furnace Friday:’ Ill-Equipped for Heat, Britain Has a Meltdown
item.media:description: Visitors to Hyde Park in London this week. “Lush parks all parched and yellow,” one Briton noted amid a long heat wave.
item.description: The monthlong heat wave has broken records, spawned wildfires and transportation delays, and has shown that the country is not prepared to cope with this weather.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Former Catalan Leader Returns to Belgium, Vowing to Defend Separatist Cause
item.media:description: The former Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont, right, and the current leader, Quim Torra, at a news conference in Brussels on Saturday.
item.description: Carles Puigdemont returned from Germany on Saturday after Spain failed in an attempt to extradite him on charges of rebellion over an illegal declaration of independence.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Prime Minister’s Eating Habits Scandalize Australians: It’s Piegate
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia set off a national debate after using a knife and fork to eat a meat pie.
item.description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull’s approach to eating a meat pie set off a debate over what was seen by some as a food faux pas.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Ontario’s Premier Flexes His Muscle by Shrinking Toronto’s Government
item.media:description: Doug Ford, the premier of Ontario, center, at a campaign rally in May. Mr. Ford plans to reduce the size of Toronto’s city government. “We have too many politicians making it harder to get things done, making it harder to get things built,” he said Friday.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Toronto leaders react with anger and shock, calling the move to reduce the size of the City Council a blow to democracy. Campaigning was already underway to fill the council seats.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Act of Defiance Casts Harsh Light on Europe’s Deportations of Asylum Seekers
item.media:description: Afghan asylum seekers deported from Germany arriving in Kabul, Afghanistan, last year.
item.description: Elin Ersson’s live-streamed protest against the deportation of an Afghan asylum seeker focused attention on the forced return of asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON and MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: G.D.P., California Wildfires, Migrants: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Ryan Donnell for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Woman Gets Five-Year Prison Sentence on Charges of Abducting Her Children
item.media:description: A Spanish court on Friday sentenced Juana Rivas to five years in prison after she ignored court orders and went into hiding for a month with her two children to avoid turning them over to their father, who had been convicted of abusing her.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Miguel Angel Molina
item.description: The woman had accused the children’s father of abuse in a case that has gripped the country and raised questions about equitable treatment in the courts.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: What Is a Genetically Modified Crop? A European Ruling Sows Confusion
item.media:description: A wheat field in Mouchamps, France. There are very few genetically modified crops grown in Europe compared to the United States.
item.description: In Europe, plants created with gene-editing technologies will be stringently regulated as G.M.O.’s. But older crops whose DNA has been altered will be left alone.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: What’s Left in Laos After a Massive Dam Collapsed
item.description: A multibillion-dollar dam, meant to boost Laos’s economy, collapsed and led to the deaths of dozens, with many still missing. Our correspondent traveled to Laos to speak with families who are trying to salvage what’s left.

item.title: Violence Is Not the New Normal: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: A vigil for 10-year-old Julianna Kozis, who died in Sunday’s shooting in Toronto.
item.description: A mass shooting in Toronto feels all too familiar for a correspondent who covered deadly attacks in London and Paris.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Arson Is Suspected in Deadly Fires in Greece, Government Says
item.media:description: A restaurant gutted by flames at the seaside resort of Mati, Greece. On Friday, the Greek government said that 84 people were confirmed to have been killed by the fires and that more than 100 people were still missing.
item.description: The death toll in the first this week rose to at least 84, with many more people still missing, in the worst disaster in the country’s recent history.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Insecurity Shadows Mali’s President. It May Also Help Him Get Re-Elected.
item.media:description: President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta of Mali in Bamako, the capital, this month. Mr. Keïta is likely to be re-elected, analysts say, in part because violence could keep many people from the polls.
item.description: Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, with a flush campaign fund and a raft of challengers, is likely to be re-elected, in part because violence could keep people from the polls.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Theater Director Returns to China With ‘Liberating and Cool’ Vision
item.media:description: Chen Shi-Zheng in New York. Throughout his career as theater director, he has mixed Western and Chinese influences in his work.
item.description: Chen Shi-Zheng, who has staged opera and theater work around the world, has not presented a public piece in his native China since 1996. He hopes two major shows in Beijing will open eyes and minds.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: As Pakistan Nears End of Vote Count, Imran Khan Is Poised to Be Next Prime Minister
item.media:description: A vendor in Islamabad, Pakistan, sitting next to images of Imran Khan, whose Pakistan Movement for Justice swept most of the country, performing strongly in urban areas. He was the military’s favored candidate.
item.description: Political rivals of Mr. Khan, who have complained about how the national election was conducted, have begun to grudgingly accept his victory.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo Settles Tax Dispute With Spain
item.media:description: Cristiano Ronaldo in Turin, Italy, this month. The Spanish authorities started to investigate his business dealings four years ago.
item.description: The Portuguese soccer star will pay about $22 million in back taxes and fines, but will avoid serving any time in jail.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: The Last Days of a Hong Kong Street for Singing Your Heart Out
item.media:description: Fans watching a busker perform this month on Sai Yeung Choi Street South in Mong Kok, Hong Kong.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: A pedestrian zone in the Mong Kok neighborhood of Hong Kong is closing after criticism that street performers have made it too loud.
item.dc:creator: MARY HUI

item.title: Delay in Sydney Jail Death Inquest Prolongs Family’s ‘Agonizing Wait’
item.media:description: Friends and relatives of David Dungay Jr. outside the Long Bay Correctional Center in Sydney in 2017.
item.description: A hearing on the death of David Dungay Jr., an Indigenous Australian who died after being pinned by correctional officers, has been adjourned until March.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: I’ve Been Covering the Detention of Terrorism Suspects for 15 Years. What Have We Learned?
item.media:description: The author after deplaning at a landing site in northeastern Syria with a military-escorted congressional delegation touring prisons for accused ISIS fighters captured by the Kurds.
item.description: Our national security law expert in Washington made his first of many reporting trips to Guantánamo Bay in 2003. Earlier this month, he toured ISIS fighter prisons in Syria.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Remains of 55 U.S. War Dead in North Korea Start Journey Home After 65 Years
item.media:description: An honor guard greeted the arrival of the remains of American servicemen returned by North Korea on Friday.
item.description: President Trump thanked North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, for the return of the remains believed to be American servicemen killed during the Korean War.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: United Nations Leader Warns of a Cash Shortage
item.media:description: Secretary General António Guterres of the United Nations said Thursday that delayed contributions by many member states had created a cash shortfall “unlike those we have experienced previously.”
item.description: Secretary General António Guterres said “delayed contributions” had caused a cash shortfall “unlike those we have experienced previously.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Despite Egypt’s Dismal Human Rights Record, U.S. Restores Military Aid
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi of Egypt, center, has enjoyed a warm relationship with President Trump, who hailed the Egyptian leader as a “fantastic guy.”
item.description: The State Department released $195 million in aid to Egypt, a year after it was blocked over concerns about President Sisi’s human rights record.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Iranian General Locks Horns With Trump, Escalating Threat-Filled Feud
item.description: Qassim Suleimani, the shadowy commander of Iran’s paramilitary Quds Force, ridiculed President Trump’s Twitter warning as “cabaret-style rhetoric.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Mueller, Syria, Trade: Your Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Hundreds Died in Syrian Custody, Government Acknowledges
item.media:description: Syrian prisoners who were released last year. Since the conflict in Syria began seven years ago, tens of thousands of people disappeared into government jails and many died in custody.
item.description: Syrian families have suddenly learned that missing relatives have been registered as dead by the government. Rights groups call it an admission that they were killed in prison.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Russia Promises to End Prison Torture. U.N. Experts Are Unconvinced.
item.media:description: Maxim Yablokov, right, a Russian prison guard, is suspected of being involved in the beating and torture of a Russian inmate, Yevgeny Makarov, in 2017.
item.description: Human rights experts pressed Russian officials over their handling of cases involving torture, including the 2017 beating of a prison inmate that was caught on video.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A #MeToo Reckoning in China’s Workplace Amid Wave of Accusations
item.media:description: The campus of Peking University. Activists see a burst of accusations of sexual harassment as a sign that China’s #MeToo movement, which had been mostly limited to universities, is spreading to the workplace.
item.description: A series of gripping letters describing abuse and harassment by journalists, intellectuals and charity leaders has lit up the Chinese internet and enlivened the country’s fledgling #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and IRIS ZHAO

item.title: Hundreds of Migrants Storm Fences to Enter Spanish Enclave in Africa
item.media:description: A migrant climbed the border fence separating Morocco and Spain’s North African enclave of Ceuta.
item.description: Spain’s Civil Guard said 600 crossed into Ceuta, adding a pressure on the country’s authorities in dealing with a wave of migration.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: An Iranian General’s Message to Trump
item.description: Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, an influential Iranian military leader, ridiculed President Trump for his tweets threatening Iran’s president.

item.title: As a Dam Rises in Ethiopia, Its Manager Is Found Dead
item.media:description: Semegnew Bekele at the Grand Renaissance Dam in Ethiopia in June. He was the project’s engineer and unofficial ambassador.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: The man overseeing an ambitious $4 billion dam project was found dead in Ethiopia’s capital early Thursday. The police said he had been shot in the head.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH, SOMINI SENGUPTA and HADRA AHMED

item.title: Mary Ellis, Who Flew British Spitfires in World War II, Dies at 101
item.media:description: Mary Ellis in Biggin Hill, England, in 2015. She took her first flying lesson as a teenager and flew for pleasure until 1940, after she heard a radio ad for female pilots to join Britain’s Air Transport Auxiliary.
item.description: She was one of the last surviving women who flew aircraft to the front lines for Britain in World War II, overcoming skepticism that women could do the job.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Trump Threatens Sanctions Against Turkey Over Detained Pastor
item.media:description: Andrew Brunson, an evangelical pastor from North Carolina, was moved to house arrest from a jail near Izmir, Turkey, on Wednesday because of health concerns.
item.description: The warming relationship between combative leaders in Turkey and the United States may cool over the house arrest of an American pastor accused of espionage.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: U.K.’s Jewish Papers Denounce Labour Party as ‘Existential Threat’
item.media:description: For months Britain’s opposition leader, Jeremy Corbyn, has been unable to close down a damaging dispute over allegations that, under his leadership, the party has failed to tackle anti-Semitism in its ranks.
item.description: Jeremy Corbyn, the opposition leader, is under fire again over anti-Semitism, this time over how his party defines it.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Duterte Signs Law Giving More Autonomy to Muslims in Southern Philippines
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Manila this month calling for a peaceful resolution to talks about more autonomy for Muslims in the south of the Philippines.
item.description: The long-delayed legislation is expected to bring some measure of peace to a region that had been choked by four decades of separatist violence.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: A Day Before Laos Dam Failed, Builders Saw Trouble
item.media:description: An aerial view of the flooded villages around the failed dam in Laos on Thursday. The collapse killed at least 27 people. Many more are still missing.
item.media:credit: Ben C. Solomon/The New York Times
item.description: Accounts of the deadly collapse raise questions about why some villagers had no warning, and about the quality of the construction work.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: New Zealand Grants Domestic Violence Victims Paid Leave
item.media:description: Members of New Zealand’s Parliament voted 63 to 57 on Wednesday to give domestic abuse survivors 10 days paid leave.
item.description: With a vote in Parliament, New Zealand joined the Philippines as the only countries in the world with such legislation, granting victims 10 days off work.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY
